lesson.name: Lesson 7.7: Building Quadratic Functions to Describe Situations, Part 3

page.title: 7.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will encounter a quadratic relationship in an economic context. You will use a table of values to study the relationship between price and revenue, write an equation to define the function, and consider what the graph of the function tells us about the situation being modeled.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Choose a domain that makes sense in a revenue situation.
  • Model revenue with quadratic functions and graphs.
  • Relate the vertex of a graph and the zeros of a function to a revenue situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.7.1: Comparing Graphs of Functions
  • 7.7.2: Modeling Real-World Data with Quadratic Functions
    • 7.7.2: Self Check
    • 7.7.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.7.3: The Domain, Vertex, and Zero of Quadratic Functions
    • 7.7.3: Self Check
    • 7.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.7.4: Relate the Domain of a Function to Its Graph

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.7.5: Practice
  • 7.7.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.7.1: Comparing Graphs of Functions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Which one doesn’t belong?

A

B

C

D

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

A is the only graph where the \(y\)-values don’t change.

B is the only graph where the \(y\)-value increases by a constant rate.

C is the only graph that is not continuous.

D is the only graph that does not intersect the \(y\)-axis at \(2\).

page.title: 7.7.2: Modeling Real-World Data with Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Activity

A company that sells movies online is deciding how much to charge customers to download a new movie. Based on data from previous sales, the company predicts that if they charge \(x\) dollars for each download, then the number of downloads, in thousands, is \(18-x\).

  1. Answer questions a–f to complete the table to show the predicted number of downloads at each listed price. The first row has been completed for you.

Price (dollars per download)

Number of downloads (thousands)

Revenue (thousands of dollars)

\(3\)

\(15\)

\(45\)

\(5\)
  1. _____
 

\(10\)
  1. _____
 

\(12\)
  1. _____
 

\(15\)
  1. _____
 

\(18\)
  1. _____
 

\(x\)
  1. _____
 
    1. When the price is \($5\) per download, what is the number of downloads in thousands?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are \(13\) thousand downloads when the price is \($5\) per download.

The correct answer is \(13\). There are \(13\) thousand downloads when the price is \($5\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($10\) per download, what is the number of downloads in thousands?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are \(8,000\) downloads when the price is \($10\) per download.

The correct answer is \(8\). There are \(8,000\) downloads when the price is \($10\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($12\) per download, what is the number of downloads in thousands?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are \(6,000\) downloads when the price is \($12\) per download.

The correct answer is \(6\). There are \(6,000\) downloads when the price is \($12\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($15\) per download, what is the number of downloads in thousands?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are \(3,000\) downloads when the price is \($15\) per download.

The correct answer is \(3\). There are \(3,000\) downloads when the price is \($15\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($18\) per download, what is the number of downloads in thousands?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are \(0\) downloads when the price is \($18\) per download.

The correct answer is \(0\). There are (0\) downloads when the price is \($18\) per download.


    1. When the price is \($x\) per download, what is the number of downloads in thousands?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(18-x\)
  1. Now, find the revenue at each price. Answer questions a–f. The first row has been completed for you.

Price (dollars per download)

Number of downloads (thousands)

Revenue (thousands of dollars)

\(3\)

\(15\)

\(45\)

\(5\)

  
  1. _____

\(10\)

  
  1. _____

\(12\)

  
  1. _____

\(15\)

  
  1. _____

\(18\)

  
  1. _____

\(x\)

  
  1. _____
    1. When the price is \($5\) per download, what is the revenue in thousands of dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is \($65,000\) when the price is \($5\) per download.

The correct answer is \(65\). The revenue is \($65,000\) when the price is \($5\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($10\) per download, what is the revenue in thousands of dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is \($80,000\) when the price is \($10\) per download.

The correct answer is \(80\). The revenue is \($80,000\) when the price is \($10\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($12\) per download, what is the revenue in thousands of dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is \($72,000\) when the price is \($12\) per download.

The correct answer is \(72\). The revenue is \($72,000\) when the price is \($12\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($15\) per download, what is the revenue in thousands of dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is \($45,000\) when the price is \($15\) per download.

The correct answer is \(45\). The revenue is \($45,000\) when the price is \($15.00\) per download.

    1. When the price is \($18\) per download, what is the revenue in thousands of dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is \(0\) when the price is \($18\) per download.

The correct answer is \(0\). The revenue is \(0\) when the price is \($18\) per download.


    1. When the price is \($x\) per download, what is the revenue in thousands of dollars?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x(18-x)\)


  1. Is the relationship between the price of the movie and the revenue (in thousands of dollars) linear, quadratic, or exponential? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is quadratic. The output \(x(18-x)\) can be written as \(18x-x^2\), which is a quadratic expression.



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course.

Plot the points that represent the revenue, \(r\), as a function of the price of one download in dollars, \(x\). Construct your graph. Be sure to label the axes.

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:


  1. What price would you recommend the company charge for a new movie? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Based on the graph, the largest revenue comes when the price is between \($5\) and \($10\). It is hard to tell exactly, but perhaps \($9\), halfway between \($0\) and \($18\).


Extending Your Thinking

The function that uses the price (in dollars per download) \(x\) to determine the number of downloads (in thousands) \(18-x\) is an example of a demand function, and its graph is known. Economists are interested in factors that can affect the demand function and therefore the price suppliers wish to set.

  1. What are some things that could increase the number of downloads predicted for the same given prices?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The quality of the movies could improve. The number of people who like watching movies could increase. The price of watching a movie in a theater could go up.

  1. If the demand shifted so that we predicted \(20-x\) thousand downloads at a price of \(x\) dollars per download, what do you think would happen to the price that gives the maximum revenue? Check what actually happens.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The price that gives the maximum revenue would increase from \($9\) to \($10\).

page.title: 7.7.2: Self Check
page.contents:
A company that sells music downloads is deciding how much to charge customers to download an album. Based on previous sales, the company predicts that if they charge \(x\) dollars for each download, then the number of downloads, in thousands, is \(13-x\).

Which of the following represents the revenue for downloads?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the number of downloads. Make sure to multiply the number of downloads by \(x\), the cost per download. The answer is \(13x-x^2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of downloads should be multiplied by \(x\), the cost per download. The answer is \(13x-x^2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \(x(13-x)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to distribute the \(x\) to both terms. The answer is \(13x-x^2\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.7.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Revenue Represented with Quadratics

Quadratic functions often come up when studying revenue. (Revenue means the money collected when someone sells something.)

Suppose we are selling raffle tickets and deciding how much to charge for each ticket. When the price of the tickets is higher, typically fewer tickets will be sold.

Each ticket has a price of \(d\) dollars, and it is possible to sell \(600-75d\) tickets. We can find the revenue by multiplying the price by the number of tickets expected to be sold. A function that models the revenue, \(r\), collected is \(r(d) = d(600-75d)\). Here is a graph that represents the function.

It makes sense that the revenue goes down after a certain point, since if the price is too high nobody will buy a ticket. From the graph, we can tell that the greatest revenue, \($1,200\), comes from selling the tickets for \($4\) each.

We can also see that the domain of the function \(r\) is between \(0\) and \(8\). This makes sense because the cost of the tickets can’t be negative, and if the price were more than \($8\), the model would not work, as the revenue collected cannot be negative. (A negative revenue would mean the number of tickets sold is negative, which is not possible.)

Try It: Revenue Represented with Quadratics

Based on past concerts, a venue expects to sell \((500 - 10p)\) tickets when each ticket is \(p\) dollars.

Write the function, \(r(p)\), to represent the revenue for the concert.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write the function for the concert revenue:

Step 1
Multiply the tickets sold by the price of each ticket, \(p\).

\(p(500 - 10p)\)

Step 2
Distribute the \(p\).

\(500p-10p^2\)

Step 3
Write as a function, \(r(p)\).

\(r(p)=500p-10p^2\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.7.3: The Domain, Vertex, and Zero of Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Here are three sets of descriptions and equations that represent some familiar quadratic functions. The graphs show what a graphing technology may produce when the equations are graphed. For each function:

  • Describe a domain that is appropriate for the situation. Think about any upper or lower limits for the input, as well as whether all numbers make sense as the input. Then, describe how the graph should be modified to show the domain that makes sense.
  • Identify or estimate the vertex on the graph. Describe what it means in the situation.
  • Identify or estimate the zeros of the function. Describe what they mean in the situation.
  1. The area of a rectangle with a perimeter of \(25\) meters and a side length \(x\): \(A(x)=x \cdot \frac {(25-2x)}{2}\)


    1. Domain:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(0<x<12.5\). All positive rational numbers make sense as an input. The part of the graph that is below the horizontal line is not meaningful here (negative lengths or lengths greater than \(12.5\) produce a negative area, which doesn’t make sense). Having a length or area equal to \(0\) doesn’t make sense either.


    1. Vertex:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex is the point on the graph when the input is at \(6.25\). It’s around \((6.25,39.063)\). It’s when the rectangle has the greatest area.


    1. Zeros:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The zeros are \(0\) and \(12.5\). They tell us that when the side length of the rectangle is \(0\) or \(12.5\) meters, the rectangle has no area (no rectangle exists).


  1. The number of squares as a function of step number \(n\): \(f(n)=n^2+4\)


    1. Domain:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(n \geq 0\) where \(n\) is a whole number. Step numbers that are negative or decimal don’t make sense here. The graph should show points at non-negative integer values (instead of a continuous curve). Everything to the left of the vertical axis does not have meaning here.


    1. Vertex:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex is \((0,4)\). It tells us the number of squares at Step \(0\).


    1. Zeros:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There are no zeros for this function. There is not a time when there are no squares in the pattern.


  1. The distance in feet that an object has fallen \(t\) seconds after being dropped: \(g(t)=16t^2\)


    1. Domain:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(t \geq 0\) or only positive numbers and \(0\). Negative values of time don’t make sense here, so the part of the graph to the left side of the vertical axis has no meaning.


    1. Vertex:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex is \((0,0)\). It tells us the distance fallen at \(0\) seconds, which is \(0\) feet.


    1. Zeros:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex also tells us the zero of the function. It’s the only time when the distance fallen is \(0\) feet.


Video: Identifying Domain, Vertex, and Zero of Quadratic Functions

Watch the following video to learn more about the domain, vertex, and zero of quadratic functions.

page.title: 7.7.3: Self Check
page.contents: Find the approximate domain of the graph below:

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(1.8\) is approximately where the maximum occurs, not the full domain. The answer is \(0 \leq x \leq 3.8\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This describes the range. The answer is \(0 \leq x \leq 3.8\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The time in seconds can be between \(0\) and almost \(4\) seconds.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Not all values above \(0\) are in the domain. The answer is \(0 \leq x \leq 3.8\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.7.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
The Meaning of Quadratic Characteristics

The height in feet of an object \(t\) seconds after being dropped is graphed below: \(h(t)=576-16t^2\).

Find the domain of the function.

  • The domain is the \(t\) values, \(0 \leq t \leq 6\) or only numbers from \(0\) up through \(6\). Negative values of time don’t make sense here, so the part of the graph to the left side of the vertical axis has no meaning. The object hits the ground \(6\) seconds after being dropped, so values greater than \(6\) are not meaningful.

Find the vertex and describe its meaning.

  • The vertex is the peak of the parabola, or the maximum, at the point \((0,576)\). It tells us the time when the height is the greatest.

Find the zeros and describe their meaning.

  • The zero of the function is \(6\). It tells us that the height of the object is \(0\) feet at \(6\) seconds after being dropped, or the time when the object hits the ground.

Try It: The Meaning of Quadratic Characteristics

Describe the zero and its meaning for the graph below:

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine the zero and its meaning:

Find where the function crosses the \(x\)-axis:

\(x=0\), \(x=16\)

Looking at the label on the \(x\)-axis, this value means that at \(0\) seconds and \(16\) seconds, the height is \(0\) feet.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.7.4: Relate the Domain of a Function to Its Graph
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

This graph represents the revenue in dollars that a company expects if they sell their product for \(p\) dollars.


  1. Based on this model, which price would generate more revenue for the company, \($5\) or \($17\)?

Correct! \($5\), as it would generate about \($3,700\) in revenue. Charging \($17\) would bring in about \($2,500\).

Incorrect. The correct answer is \($5\), as it would generate about \($3,700\) in revenue. Charging \($17\) would bring in about \($2,500\).


  1. At what price (in dollars) should the company sell their product if they wish to make as much revenue as possible?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Based on the graph, a price of \($10\) would bring in the most revenue.

The correct answer is \(10\). Based on the graph, a price of \($10\) would bring in the most revenue.

  1. How much revenue (in dollars) would they make?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Based on the graph, a price of \($10\) would bring in about \($5,000\).

The correct answer is \($5,000\). Based on the graph, a price of \($10\) would bring in about \($5,000\).


  1. What is an appropriate domain for the function? Explain how you know.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(0 \leq p \leq 20\), because the price has to be non-negative, and the company would earn negative revenue if the price were more than \($20\).

page.title: 7.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the following to answer questions 1–5.

Based on past musical productions, a theater predicts selling \(400-8p\) tickets when each ticket is sold at \(p\) dollars.

  1. Answer questions a–g to complete the middle column in the table to find out how many tickets the theater expects to sell and what revenues it expects to receive at the given ticket prices.

Ticket price (dollars)

Number of tickets sold

Revenue (dollars)

\(5\)

\(360\)

\(1800\)

\(10\)

a. _____

  

\(15\)

b. _____

  

\(20\)

c. _____

  

\(30\)

d. _____

  

\(45\)

e. _____

  

\(50\)

f. _____

  

\(p\)

g. _____

  

    1. When the price is \($10\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 320 tickets sold when the price is $10 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 320. There are 320 tickets sold when the price is $10 per ticket. 

    1. When the price is \($15\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 280 tickets sold when the price is $15 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 280. There are 280 tickets sold when the price is $15 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($20\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 240 tickets sold when the price is $20 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 240. There are 240 tickets sold when the price is $20 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($30\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 160 tickets sold when the price is $30 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 160. There are 160 tickets sold when the price is $30 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($45\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 40 tickets sold when the price is $45 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 40. There are 40 tickets sold when the price is $45 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($50\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 0 tickets sold when the price is $50 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. There are 0 tickets sold when the price is $50 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \(p\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Correct! \(400-8p\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(400-8p\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer questions a-g to complete the right column in the table to find out what revenues the theater expects to receive at the given ticket prices.

Ticket price (dollars)

Number of tickets sold

Revenue (dollars)

\(5\)

\(360\)

\(1800\)

\(10\)

  

a. _____

\(15\)

  

b. _____

\(20\)

  

c. _____

\(30\)

  

d. _____

\(45\)

  

e. _____

\(50\)

  

f. _____

\(p\)

  

g. _____

    1. When the price is \($10\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $3,200 when the price is $10 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3,200. The revenue is $3,200 when the price is $10 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($15\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $4,200 when the price is $15 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4,200. The revenue is $4,200 when the price is $15 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($20\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $20 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4,800. The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $20 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($30\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $30 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4,800. The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $30 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($45\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $1,800 when the price is $45 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1,800. The revenue is $1,800 when the price is $45 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($50\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is zero when the price is $50 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The revenue is zero when the price is $50 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \(p\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Correct! \(p(400-8p)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(p(400-8p)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For which ticket price, listed in the table, will the theater earn no revenue?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is zero when the ticket price is $50.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 50. The revenue is zero when the ticket price is $50. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Calculate the lowest price of a ticket that the theater should sell the tickets for if it must earn at least \($3,200\) in revenue to break even (to not lose money) on the musical production. (The calculated value may not be listed in the table.)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The lowest price the theater should charge to at least make $3,200 and break even is $10 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 10. The lowest price the theater should charge to at least make $3,200 and break even is $10 per ticket. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Calculate the highest price of a ticket that the theater should sell the tickets for if it must earn at least \($3,200\) in revenue to break even (to not lose money) on the musical production. (The calculated value may not be listed in the table.)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The highest price the theater should charge to make at least $3,200 and break even is $40 per ticket. Although not shown in the table, we can calculate that when \(p\) is $40, the expected revenue is \(40(400-8(40))\) or \(40 \cdot 80\), which is $3,200.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 40. The highest price the theater should charge to at least make $3,200 and break even is $40 per ticket. Although not shown in the table, we can calculate that when \(p\) is $40, the expected revenue is \(40(400-8(40)\) or \(40 \cdot 80\), which is $3,200. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A company sells running shoes. If the price of a pair of shoes in dollars is \(p\), the company estimates that it will sell \(50,000-400p\) pairs of shoes.

    Which expression represents the revenue in dollars from selling running shoes if a pair of shoes is priced at \(p\) dollars?

Correct! \((50,000-400p) \cdot p\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((50,000-400p) \cdot p\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 7–9.

The function \(f\) represents the revenue in dollars the school can expect to receive if it sells \(220-12x\) coffee mugs for \(x\) dollars each.

Here is the graph of \(f\).

  1. Select three statements that describe this situation.

Correct! The school expects to sell 160 mugs if the price is $5 each. The school will earn about $1,000 if it sells the mugs for $10 each. The revenue will be more than $700 if the price is between $4 and $14.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The school expects to sell 160 mugs if the price is $5 each. The school will earn about $1,000 if it sells the mugs for $10 each. The revenue will be more than $700 if the price is between $4 and $14. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. To the nearest hundred dollars, what is the maximum revenue for the mugs?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1000

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1,000. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which is the approximate domain?

Correct! \(0 \leq x \leq 18\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(0 \leq x \leq 18\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Choose a domain that makes sense in a revenue situation.
  • Model revenue with quadratic functions and graphs.
  • Relate the vertex of a graph and the zeros of a function to a revenue situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.7.1: Comparing Graphs of Functions
    • In this activity, you analyzed and compared the features of the graphs of four different functions.
  • 7.7.2: Modeling Real-World Data with Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you analyzed the relationship between the price of downloading a movie and the number of downloads. You modeled and graphed the relationship as a quadratic function that showed the revenue as a function of the price of the download. You used this function, referred to as the demand function, to predict profit price points.
    • 7.7.2: Self Check
    • 7.7.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.7.3: The Domain, Vertex, and Zero of Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you looked at appropriate domains for quadratic functions given the situations they represented. You identified and estimated the vertex of the graph and the zeros of the functions. You used modeling and graphing to interpret upper or lower limits for the input, as well as whether all numbers made sense.
    • 7.7.3: Self Check
    • 7.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.7.4: Relate the Domain of a Function to Its Graph
    • In this activity, you analyzed a graph that represented the revenue that a company would expect to see if they sell their product at a certain price. You used this information to determine an appropriate domain for the function of the graph.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.7.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
